title: How to get inside the mind of a serial killer
text:
Attempting to understand the mind of a serial killer involves asking some serious questions about why they do the things they do

For years some of the world’s top psychiatrists have been trying to answer one question: what makes a serial killer tick?

How did they get away with multiple crimes before being caught? Where did their childhoods go so wrong? And, most terrifyingly, what drove them to commit such heinous crimes?

This month, Sky Crime, the new home of true crime, launched with the most compelling cases from the UK and US, allowing us to get under the skin of a serial killer like never before.

Among the fascinating true crime documentaries are Kemper On Kemper: Inside The Mind Of A Serial Killer, Mark Of A Killer and In Defense Of, which all delve deeper into the real-life stories behind these notorious attackers – and their hideous crimes.

So, how do we begin to try and understand the mind of a serial killer?

Sky Crime documentary Kemper on Kemper gives a unique insight into the crimes of ‘Co-Ed Killer’ Ed Kemper, told in his own words

Who is ED KEMPER? ‘The Co-Ed Killer’ Six-foot-nine US serial killer Edmund Kemper is explored in the Sky Crime documentary Kemper on Kemper: Inside The Mind Of A Serial Killer. The investigation explores how a highly-intelligent Californian man, also known as the Co-Ed Killer, went on to murder and dismember 10 people, including his own mother. Was Kemper a product of a troubled upbringing, or was he born to kill? In an eye opening interview, Kemper reveals how he obsessed over death from a young age, initially killing his family pet and soon leading to the murder of his own grandparents by the age of 15. So, when he turned himself in the 1970s after a lifetime of cold-blooded murders, how could he possibly still be declared sane?

The FBI has been profiling ‘multiple murderers’ since the mid-1940s, when it was first decided that there may be similarities that link these types of criminals together, as well as intricacies to their crimes that set them apart.

They defined a ‘serial murder’ as ‘the unlawful killing of two or more victims by the same offender(s), in separate events’ and devised official methods to analyse these types of behaviours that investigators still use today.

Often, it begins with dissecting the crimes themselves, asking whether the murderer kills in the same way each time or targets a certain type of person.

Research suggests that overall, men and women are equal targets for serial killers in the US, although the choice of victim is far from haphazard.

Sky Crime, the new home of true crime, launches this month with a raft of thrilling documentaries unpicking the cases of serial killers, like Mark Of A Killer

Who is DANNY ROLLING? ‘Gainesville Ripper’ Episode one of Sky Crime’s Mark Of A Killer takes a closer look at Danny Rolling, aka The Gainesville Ripper, whose three-day rampage left five Florida students dead in 1990. Despite meticulously covering his tracks with cleaning solvents, he left disturbing clues that linked his crimes together. So, did Rolling want to be caught? Or, was this a cunning way to taunt the police? When the serial killer was finally captured, with his father being the last person he tried to kill before his crime spree ended, it led many to ask what motivated his heinous crimes.

This latest documentary examines the murderer in an extremely unique way as he explains in his own words why he went on a 20-year killing spree.

Was he motivated by power, vengeance, notoriety or greed? Or is there something fundamentally different about Ed Kemper, and other serial killers, that drove them to these crimes?

Research with over 3,000 of these murderers has found that 32 per cent say ‘enjoyment’ was the reason they carried out their crimes, which could explain why some criminals leave a calling card at the scene to taunt police.

The Sky Crime documentary Mark Of A Killer identifies the various clues and symbols that killers such as the ‘Gainesville Ripper’ and the ‘Dating Game Killer’ left behind, dissecting the disturbing traits of these attackers.

Convicting a person accused of multiple murders can be harder than it seems, like the curious case of Robert Durst as documented in The Jinx (Picture: 2019 Home Box Office, Inc. All Rights Reserved)

Who is ROBERT DURST? ‘The Jinx’ The case against New York real estate heir Robert Durst has now spanned almost four decades – and it’s still not over. Sky Crime documentary, The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst, tells the unbelievable story of how suspected triple killer Durst has evaded jail time for crimes he is continuously linked to. In 2004, Durst was cleared of murdering his neighbour, Morris Black, despite dismembering his body and dumping it in a river. So, if Durst is capable of killing someone, how did he get away with it? More to the point, will the same thing happen when Durst goes on trial in 2020 for the murder of his best friend and confidante Susan Berman in 2000? Perhaps we’ll know whether Berman’s death had anything to do with the disappearance of Durst’s first wife Kathleen McCormack in 1982, and if so, finally discover what Durst has to do with both cases.

Do these patterns indicate a desire to be caught? Or, could these clues be part of a sick game that adds to the killer’s ‘enjoyment’ or feeling of dominance over authority?

Interestingly, nearly half of all multiple murderers in the US now get caught after two killings compared to 40 years ago, when nearly one in three serial killers got away with five or more.

Yet it’s convicting these criminals that is sometimes the most complex part of the story.

Take the curious case of New York real estate heir Robert Durst who has been accused of multiple murders.

The fascinating twists and turns are examined in Sky Crime documentary The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst, asking how the multi-millionaire got away with potentially three murders of the people closet to him. Was it a string of a bad luck or cold blooded killing?

In Defense Of is the documentary that shows the conflict of defending a multiple murderer

Who is TED BUNDY? The Campus Killer Ted Bundy is still one of the most complex serial killers the world has ever known about. Certainly this presentable, well-mannered and educated man didn’t seem like a mass murderer in court, which made people question whether police had captured the wrong man. Surely, the Bundy in the media and on television screens wasn’t an evil man, so what made him into a serial killer and does it explain his crimes? Moreover, in the case of one of the most prolific killing sprees in history, how does anyone go about defending him? Sky Crime’s In Defense Of now speaks to criminal defense attorney John Henry Browne, the man tasked with representing Bundy, asking was Bundy born evil? And if you believe so, how does it feel to sit next to a man in court accused of being one of America’s sickest and most sophisticated serial killers?

Then there’s the eye-opening true crime series, In Defense Of, also airing on Sky Crime this October, which gives unprecedented access to the attorneys tasked with representing defendants accused of multiple murders.

Each standalone episode covers a different high-profile case, featuring the defense lawyers from the trials of Branch Davidians member Clive Doyle and serial killer Ted Bundy, allowing us to unpick the facts of their cases and make up our own mind about their guilt, motives or sentence.

And finally, is there a personal cost or professional impact of defending such notorious clients, and if their conviction hinges on the killer’s mental state, can they still be held accountable for their crimes?

Delve deeper into the minds of killers by tuning in to watch Kemper on Kemper, The Jinx, Mark Of A Killer and In Defense Of on brand new channel, Sky Crime, the new home of true crime.
